macOS Setup Guide

http://sourabhbajaj.com/mac-setup/index.html

NFS mounts

How to get it to work:
http://blog.fosketts.net/2015/03/20/using-nfs-to-share-data-between-unix-and-mac-os-x/

Something like this in the /etc/exports file:

ip-addr     addrs-to-export-to(rw,async,insecure,all_squash,no_subtree_check,anonuid=1001,anongid=1001)

Make sure the id’s match those you want the Mac to assume.

Now you can mount like this:

sudo mount -t nfs 192.168.3.1:/mp3 /private/nfs

I haven’t read the entire thing yet so might be I missed something but I wasn’t able to transfer files to the server. In order to get that to work I had to add the -o nolocks option when mounting. https://discussions.apple.com/thread/1394583?start=0&tstart=0
Detailed post on this:
http://www.mauserrifle.nl/linux/osx-and-linux-nfs-shares/

If the insecure option is not an option use this:

https://www.cyberciti.biz/faq/apple-mac-osx-nfs-mount-command-tutorial/

sudo mount -t nfs -o resvport,rw 192.168.3.1:/mp3 /private/nfs

With or without the rw it gave me the permission denied warning unless I was root. So only viable if don’t need to write access.

Other stuff pertaining to this:

This person seems to have a clue on what is going on at a deep level of understanding should read some day.
http://www.linuxquestions.org/questions/linux-networking-3/permission-denied-on-nfs-mount-4175500991/

“Correct” fix have uses with same uid/gid on both mac and unix sounds like too much work:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/23037893/permission-denied-with-mounting-nfs-with-webmin-mac-osx-ubuntu-setup

Create a new group and assign it a specific GID:
System Preferences -> Users & Groups, unlock to make changes hit the + to add a new user account on the New Account dropdown select group. Give it a name then Create Group.

Now the group should appear under Groups on the left-hand side right-click select Advanced Options… then select the new GID.

Might work for new users haven’t tested it.

Some command-line options for this.
Group:
http://superuser.com/questions/74342/create-specific-gid-for-a-group-and-add-a-user-to-it-on-mac-os-x-10-5

User:
http://apple.stackexchange.com/questions/226073/how-do-i-create-user-accounts-from-the-terminal-in-mac-os-x-10-11

iTerm

cmd + option + v Advanced paste allows you to edit before you paste.

cmd + option + b Allows you to go backwards in time and see what happened in the terminal sort of like that one thing that records stuff but can’t remember its name…

Prefs > Keys > Show/Hide iTerm2 with a system-wide hotkey

Prefs > Profiles > Colors - Highlights the line you are on
cmd + option + ; - to activate it

cmd + option + a - Get informed when a long-running command completes.

Need to read what this does and how to do it…

With Shell Integration installed, you can select the output of the last command with shift cmd a
https://iterm2.com/documentation-shell-integration.html

cmd + / shows where the cursor is.

Settings

If a program is in another language then go to System Preferences -> Language & Region and under Preferred languages delete all languages other than the one you want. Yes, even if it isn’t the first one it can still mess things up. GIMP, for instance, seems want to be in any language other than English.

Something else that I myself haven’t tested out:

http://www.ekenberg.se/blog/change-gimp-interface-language-on-mac/

I think the steps would be:

# Back up the file before working on it
cp /Applications/GIMP.app/Contents/MacOS/GIMP ~/gimp.bak

vim /Applications/GIMP.app/Contents/MacOS/GIMP

The file should be a shell script not a binary file (run the file command on the file to make sure, if you want). Scroll all the way to the bottom of the file Shift+g, then Shift+o (this adds a line before the last line, which should begin with exec) and add this:

export LANG=en_US.UTF-8

If another language is desired run locale -a to see all the valid values. (e.g. sv_SE.UTF-8)
